newsitem.title: USA: Dow ekes out narrow gain, techs roar higher.
newsitem.headline: Dow ekes out narrow gain, techs roar higher.

text.p: Wall Street stocks finished higher on Monday, with tech stocks extending their torrid run and blue chips scratching out the slenderest of gains.
The Dow industrials rose one point to 7923, led higher for the second straight session by computer maker Hewlett-Packard Co, which gained 3-7/8 to 65-1/16 in New York Stock Exchange trading.
The Nasdaq Composite jumped more than 21 points, running its streak of consecutive record closes to eight, as investors flocked to the suddenly sizzling tech sector.

The tech stock rally, which appears to be gaining momentum, faces a critical series of earnings-related tests this week, with reports due from industry bellwether companies Intel Corp and Microsoft Corp.
"We get Intel tomorrow and Microsoft on Thursday," said Guy Truicko, "and this trend could either break or continue right on, based on what those two companies say."

Intel warned in late May that its second-quarter earnings would fall short of earlier estimates because of product transition issues. Investors have apparently decided the worst is already passed, analysts said.
"Right now, the market is certainly telling us it expects good news," Truicko said.
Shares in Intel rose 1-7/8 to 78-3/4 and Microsoft surged 6-3/16 to 135-15/16.
While tech stocks have shot higher, the Dow has stalled a bit, remaining stuck just below 8000 since closing at 7895.81 on July 3.

While analysts are not expecting a sharp, sustained decline by the blue chips, they say the 8000 milestone may remain elusive for a while longer, as investors flock to the tech group, which is suddenly back in favor.

"Many players in the large caps were there for the short term, and they don't want to be buying here, when a lot of those stocks are quite expensive," said Peggy Farley, chief executive at Amas Securities.
"On the other hand, a lot of the techs had been neglected or just overlooked," she said. "Once they started going up, people just got more comfortable with them again."
Quarterly corporate earnings season started in earnest Monday, with a flurry of releases from banking companies that reported profits in line with or slightly above forecasts.

Among banks reporting Monday were NationsBank Corp, which rose 11/16 to close at 67-5/16, First Chicago NBD Corp, which rose 7/16 to 63-7/16, and Bank of New York Co Inc, which finished up 1/4 at 46-1/8.

Investment bank Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Inc jumped 1-7/8 to 58-15/16 after reporting earnings of $1.49 per share on a diluted basis, off from $1.53 a year ago but well ahead of First Call's consensus estimate of $1.20.
Health-care information provider HCIA Inc plummeted 16-3/8 to 15-5/8 after saying it expected a second-quarter loss of between $0.15 and $0.18 per share.
Analysts had expected the company to post a profit of $0.30 per share for the quarter, according to First Call.
Chemicals producer DuPont Co fell 15/16 to 62-5/16 after announcing an agreement to buy several chemicals businesses from Imperial Chemical Industries Plc for a total of $3 billion.
American Depositary shares in Imperial Chemical rose 3-5/8 to 59-7/8.
The S&P 500 index rose 1.70 points to 918.38.
The Nasdaq Composite rose 21.26 points to 1523.88.
((-- Wall Street desk, 212-859-1730))
